hedline.hl1: New Video Game Glasses Do Your Blinking for You

block.p: Inveterate video game players now crave the kind of hard-edged realism you can find only by sitting in your parents' basement, staring at a monitor. Elsa Technologies has tried to introduce another dimension into the video game experience with the 3-D Revelator. The glasses use L.C.D. shutters that open and close over alternating eyes 120 times per second. That creates the mental effect of seeing the video image from two angles. Inveterate video game players now crave the kind of hard-edged realism you can find only by sitting in your parents' basement, staring at a monitor. Elsa Technologies has tried to introduce another dimension into the video game experience with the 3-D Revelator. The glasses use L.C.D. shutters that open and close over alternating eyes 120 times per second. That creates the mental effect of seeing the video image from two angles. (Otherwise the imageappears out of register.)

The 3-D Revelator works only with the DirectX platform. The glasses also require an nVidia graphics card and a monitor that refreshes at least 100 times each second. The company sells two models of the Revelator, a pair with wires that sells for $55 and a wireless version, useful for when you get dizzy and fall out of your chair, for $75.
